title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly identify the intermolecular forces in both compounds.

· Compound Q – dispersion forces

· Compound X – dispersion forces, dipole-dipole forces, and hydrogen bonding

The response correctly identifies the intermolecular forces in both compounds.

· Compound Q – dispersion forces

· Compound X – dispersion forces, dipole-dipole forces, and hydrogen bonding

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide a correct explanation equivalent to the following.

· The greater number of atoms in compound X leads to a larger, more polarizable electron cloud than in compound Q, and correspondingly stronger London dispersion forces. Compound X also has relatively strong dipole-dipole forces and hydrogen bonding. Because the total of all intermolecular forces in compound X is greater than that in compound Q, compound X has the higher boiling point.

The response provides a correct explanation equivalent to the following.

· The greater number of atoms in compound X leads to a larger, more polarizable electron cloud than in compound Q, and correspondingly stronger London dispersion forces. Compound X also has relatively strong dipole-dipole forces and hydrogen bonding. Because the total of all intermolecular forces in compound X is greater than that in compound Q, compound X has the higher boiling point.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct answer and a valid explanation equivalent to the following.

· No. The activation energies indicated by the relative heights of the peaks are consistent with the second step being rate-determining, but the relative position of the reactants and products is incorrect. The higher energy of the products relative to the reactants indicates an endothermic reaction, not an exothermic reaction.

The response provides correct answer and a valid explanation equivalent to the following.

· No. The activation energies indicated by the relative heights of the peaks are consistent with the second step being rate-determining, but the relative position of the reactants and products is incorrect. The higher energy of the products relative to the reactants indicates an endothermic reaction, not an exothermic reaction.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct answer and a valid justification equivalent to one of the following.

· No. The linear relationship between ln  [ C 2 H 6 O] MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43FD@ vs. time is consistent with a first order reaction, not a second order reaction.

OR

· No. The slope of the line is − 0 .20 min −1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4384@ , which is inconsistent with both the mathematical sign and units of a second order process. A second order reaction would give a line with a positive slope (equal to k) and have a rate constant with units of M −1 min −1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4052@ , rather than min −1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D9D@ .

The response provides both the correct answer and a valid justification equivalent to one of the following.

· No. The linear relationship between ln  [ C 2 H 6 O] MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43FD@ vs. time is consistent with a first order reaction, not a second order reaction.

OR

· No. The slope of the line is − 0 .20 min −1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4384@ , which is inconsistent with both the mathematical sign and units of a second order process. A second order reaction would give a line with a positive slope (equal to k) and have a rate constant with units of M −1 min −1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4052@ , rather than min −1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D9D@ .
